RELEASE/1.4.commit_message: Fix build on platforms with SO_NOSIGPIPE

Avoid triggering SIGPIPE in library code

On Unix-like platforms we want to avoid generating SIGPIPE when writing
to a socket when the other end has been closed since signals break the
encapsulation of what we're doing inside the library - either user code
would need to handle the SIGPIPE, or we set a signal handler for SIGPIPE
but that would handle *any* SIGPIPE in the process, not just those we
might trigger, and that could break user code which expects to trigger
and handle SIGPIPE.

We don't need SIGPIPE since we can check errno==EPIPE instead (which is
actually simpler to do).

It seems all current Unix-like platforms now support SO_NOSIGPIPE or
MSG_NOSIGNAL, so currently we just fall back to setting SIGPIPE to
SIG_IGN.  If there are actually current platforms which have SIGPIPE
without SO_NOSIGPIPE or MSG_NOSIGNAL then we can look at other ways to
avoid generating the signal.

(cherry picked from commit 01d1b53445d9c8c23108449ed945cb39df2307bf)

[glass] Eliminate unnecessary memory allocations

When committing changes, we were allocating blocks for all levels of the
built-in cursor in each writable table, even those that weren't in use.

The worst case is a really small database with all optional tables
existing which would have 54 unused allocations of blocksize + 8 bytes,
which with the default 8K block size is ~432KB per WritableDatabase;
if you explicitly ask for 64K block size it'll be ~3.4MB.

For a more typical WritableDatabase it's probably going to be more like
half these numbers.

matches shell behaviour and also the existing comment above this code.

likely to be encountered, and the previous behaviour doesn't appear
to have any security consequences (if an attacker is able to specify the
commands omindex runs to extract text from files then you have a problem
already).

[ci] Overhaul GHA configuration

There's now a "makedist" job which generates tarballs and stores them
in an artifact, and that's fetched and used by all the other build
jobs.

This has a number of benefits:

* It helps shake out bugs in "make dist" (this change uncovered a
  missing testdata file in the xapian-letor tarball)

* It reduces the amount of redundant work that CI has to do

* Cross-builds no longer need to do a native build just to get the
  tree bootstrapped.

* It's easier to add jobs for new platforms (via docker containers etc)
  as you don't need find a way to install the extra tools that
  bootstrapping the source tree requires, which may not be handily
  packaged.

Really really fix _FORTIFY_SOURCE vs mingw-w64

Including a header to check if we're on mingw-w64 results in processing
the current _FORTIFY_SOURCE setting, and we can't then usefully change
it based on whether we're on mingw-w64 or not.

Just take the simpler approach of not auto-enabling _FORTIFY_SOURCE on
mingw or mingw-w64.  It doesn't work on the latter without -lssp, and
I can't find evidence it's even supported on the former anyway.  If it
is, enabling manually will still work.

Really really fixes #808.

Fix thread-safety issue starting remote prog

Previously we did some memory allocation in the child process after
fork() before we exec-ed the specified program, but in a multi-threaded

Fix recovery from failed commit

If renaming to switch the new version file live fails (e.g. due to
ENOSPC) we discard the changes, try to write and switch to a different
new version file with an increased revision (on failure of this too we
close the database), and throw DatabaseError.

Unfortunately the roll-back of state is not complete, and if switching
to the different new version file succeeds that bad state persists on
disk.

Thanks to Uwe Kleine-König for reporting and coming up with the idea
to reproduce using strace to inject a rename() failure - this is a
simple reproducer:

rm -rf enospc.db
strace -e inject=rename:error=ENOSPC:when=2 examples/simpleindex enospc.db < INSTALL
xapian-check enospc.db

No automated regression test for this yet as this doesn't trivially
fit into the existing testsuite framework, but we ought to have
tests using fault injection.

[php] Redo functor reference tracking

We need to keep hold of a reference to Xapian functor objects which are
subclassed in PHP.  We were trying to use Xapian's optional reference
counting for this, but it turns out that doesn't work in the case where
the functor is set then the object it is set on is deleted, and then
the same functor object is set on another object.

It appears to be impossible to make Xapian's optional reference counting
work with SWIG director objects, so go back to keeping references via
PHP properties, but now implemented in C++ code rather than PHP code
because the classes are no longer defined in a xapian.php wrapper.

Workaround NFS issue in testsuite rm_rf()

This function is used to remove databases by the testharness.

On NFS, rmdir() can fail with EEXIST or ENOTEMPTY (POSIX allows either)
due to .nfs* files which are used by NFS clients to implement the Unix
semantics of a deleted but open file continuing to exist.  We now sleep
and retry a few times in this situation to give the NFS client a chance
to process the closing of the open handle.

Clean up handling of libs we link libxapian with

Previously any libraries explicitly specified to configure by the
user via LIBS=... and also -lm, if configure determined it is needed,
could get added to XAPIAN_LIBS multiple times, as well as also getting
added to the libxapian link command anyway as per automake/libtool
standard handling.

Now they'll only get added once, via the default handling.

Specifying a library more than once on the link line is not a problem
on common platforms, but may be an issue somewhere (and it's on less
common platforms where the user might have to specify LIBS to configure
and/or where -lm may be needed).

Enable -fno-semantic-interposition if supported

This GCC option allows the compiler to optimise essentially assuming
that functions/variables aren't replaced at dynamic link time.

Such replacement is not something that it's useful to do for Xapian
symbols, and we already turn on -Bsymbolic-functions by default which
prevents such replacement anyway by resolving references within the
library at build time.

Reduces the size of the stripped library on x86-64 Debian unstable by
~1%, and likely makes it faster too.

(cherry picked from commit 29bb8b5a3e1c0e14898acb8fe56c177f098aeecd)

Add QueryParser::FLAG_NO_POSITIONS flag

With this flag enabled, no positional information will be used and any
query operations which would use it are replaced by the nearest
equivalent which doesn't (so phrase searches, NEAR and ADJ will result
in OP_AND).  This is intended to replace the automatic conversion of
OP_PHRASE, etc to OP_AND when a database has no positional information,
which we stopped doing recently on git master.

Compile error for adding Database to WritableDatabase

Add inline WritableDatabase::add_database(const WritableDatabase&) method
which (by C++ rules) will prevent WritableDatabase from automatically
inheriting method Database::add_database(const Database&) so attempting
to add a Database to a WritableDatabase will now give a compile-time
error.

Prior to 1.4.19, this compiled and effectively created a "black-hole"
shard which quietly discarded any changes made to it.

Already fixed on git master.  On this branch it's still possible to
perform this operation by assigning the WritableDatabase to a Database
first, but this gives an error on git master.

Reported by David Bremner on #xapian.

Avoid checking for permissions on every query

Only queries which use positional information now check, which
should help improve notmuch delete performance.  Thanks to andreas
on #notmuch for analysis of the problem.

This change isn't relevant to git master, since there we've dropped
the feature of changing OP_PHRASE and OP_NEAR to OP_AND if there
are no positions in the database being searched.

ci-mingw32-cross-docker.commit_message: [ci] Try to replicate #821 failure
[ci] Prune back CI jobs

Fix mingw32 build with C++17 compiler

This ends up with std::byte conflicting with byte typedefs in system
headers, due to `using namespace std;` in some of our internal headers.
Switch the problematic ones to more targetted `using std::string;`, etc
to fix this.

This change is specific to RELEASE/1.4 as we completely cleaned up git
master to use explicit std:: qualifying in internal headers, but that
seemed too invasive to backport (also the code has changed so much that
the 1.4 version would need many additional changes).

Fix WIN32 build with --disable-backend-remote

The build was failing because we were always trying to build
common/socket_utils.cc which fails because SOCKLEN_T hasn't been
probed.

Fixes #821, reported by mgautier.

(cherry picked from commit 71ba7b1853431a9e39ad63d9389057594441f6f4)

[python2] Fix Query ctor for OP_WILDCARD queries

Equivalent fix to that just applied for Python3.

[python] Fix Query ctor for OP_WILDCARD queries

Previously the overload resolution typecheck typemap used
PySequence_Check() to check for a Python sequence, but that
treats a string as a sequence of characters, whereas we only want to
accept a sequence of strings and/or xapian.Query objects so expand
the check to excludes strings.

(cherry picked from commit d4fd3fad32a7560087c9361d387a29dc68de7c18)

Fix fallback code for old libmagic

The code we were using seems like it would never have worked as the
return value from magic_file() is const char* and it seems also was back
then.  Nobody's reported this (I noticed while looking at the code) so
we could just require libmagic >= 4.22, but it's trivial to actually
handle so let's fix the fallback code and keep it for now.

Clean up commented out code left from backporting

Fix recovery from failed commit

If renaming to switch the new version file live fails (e.g. due to
ENOSPC) we discard the changes, try to write and switch to a different
new version file with an increased revision (on failure of this too we
close the database), and throw DatabaseError.

Unfortunately the roll-back of state is not complete, and if switching
to the different new version file succeeds that bad state persists on
disk.

Thanks to Uwe Kleine-König for reporting and coming up with the idea
to reproduce using strace to inject a rename() failure - this is a
simple reproducer:

rm -rf enospc.db
strace -e inject=rename:error=ENOSPC:when=2 examples/simpleindex enospc.db < INSTALL
xapian-check enospc.db

No automated regression test for this yet as this doesn't trivially
fit into the existing testsuite framework, but we ought to have
tests using fault injection.

[php] Redo functor reference tracking

We need to keep hold of a reference to Xapian functor objects which are
subclassed in PHP.  We were trying to use Xapian's optional reference
counting for this, but it turns out that doesn't work in the case where
the functor is set then the object it is set on is deleted, and then
the same functor object is set on another object.

work with SWIG director objects, so go back to keeping references via
PHP properties, but now implemented in C++ code rather than PHP code

Stop trying to check for incompatible GCC ABI

using the latest ABI version it supports.  The result is that this check

No-op GlassTable::readahead_key for overlong keys

Currently, a query may abort with an InvalidArgument error if one of
the terms exceeds the maximum allowed length for glass btree keys.
However, this error is thrown only if the query triggers a readahead_key
call on the glass table.

This patch updates readahead_key to report overlong keys as not found,
rather than aborting the whole query.

scriptindex: Fix weird error cases

In four cases while handling input data (two cases of bad hex data fed
to `hextobin`, an input data line without a `=`, and `load` failing to
load the specified file) we'd emit a diagnostic that was labelled as an
"error" but really it was handled as a warning as we kept reading input
and the "error" didn't affect the exit status.

Workaround NFS issue in testsuite rm_rf()

This function is used to remove databases by the testharness.

On NFS, rmdir() can fail with EEXIST or ENOTEMPTY (POSIX allows either)
due to .nfs* files which are used by NFS clients to implement the Unix
semantics of a deleted but open file continuing to exist.  We now sleep
and retry a few times in this situation to give the NFS client a chance
to process the closing of the open handle.

added to the libxapian link command anyway as per automake/libtool
standard handling.

With this change, OP_ELITE_SET can now select a different subset of
terms for each shard regardless of shard type (previously this only
happened for remote shards), so document that.

(cherry picked from commit 1be18076dc25f7ce0fcbf44e09fa370a4a436464)

Add $base64 OmegaScript command

(cherry picked from commit 74df7696f8603add68c6fda27e44dda2b7090093)

Clean up extern variables

Make two static to the only file they are actually used in.

(cherry picked from commit 07bf4dc3a793d12e117be851335c64442d997154)
Update NEWS from git log

Update from freenode to libera.chat

(cherry picked from commit 7c993a621a5ff99689ac9f66e6f36199b8f98a8e)

ci: Notify travis-ci via matrix not freenode

(cherry picked from commit 15a8a4bc4f50fffcdc425c237ad38ad192d94d96)

Enable -fno-semantic-interposition if supported

This GCC option allows the compiler to optimise essentially assuming
that functions/variables aren't replaced at dynamic link time.

Such replacement is not something that it's useful to do for Xapian
symbols, and we already turn on -Bsymbolic-functions by default which
prevents such replacement anyway by resolving references within the
library at build time.

Reduces the size of the stripped library on x86-64 Debian unstable by
~1%, and likely makes it faster too.

(cherry picked from commit 29bb8b5a3e1c0e14898acb8fe56c177f098aeecd)

Add QueryParser::FLAG_NO_POSITIONS flag

With this flag enabled, no positional information will be used and any
query operations which would use it are replaced by the nearest
equivalent which doesn't (so phrase searches, NEAR and ADJ will result
in OP_AND).  This is intended to replace the automatic conversion of
OP_PHRASE, etc to OP_AND when a database has no positional information,
which we stopped doing recently on git master.

(cherry picked from commit f19d469662d9b2c71394207b8d1eb6f12bf3d98b)

Remove stale entries from .gitignore

(cherry picked from commit 97d998377afc1d1b37c3f8072592e9dd886814ac)

python3: Remove more files/dirs on "make clean"

Reported by Gaurav Arora.

(cherry picked from commit 5e06037f5d9d92d8cba3ed219494a978c50de17e)

scriptindex: Report location of previous unique

(cherry picked from commit 775d50da50cddc1e3ea5b8690cb2342eff6fbd23)

Fix another deprecation warning with Python >= 3.9

(cherry picked from commit 3340525dd853bcb92927f63314e15e7554e37910)

Fix deprecation warning with Python >= 3.9

(cherry picked from commit f30d64fe42c7bdf46c5871fbbe1d8eb6ddf3f480)

Note when ltrim/rtrim/squash/trim were added

(cherry picked from commit 4e6be2e350e5c97953d6643646cd7e969bb7d990)

Add new scriptindex whitespace removal actions

Implement `ltrim`, `rtrim`, `squash`, and `trim` actions which clean up
whitespace in the text in various ways.

(cherry picked from commit 85aee22df6d5686d117beb333025c950cd9c9249)

Compile error for adding Database to WritableDatabase

Add inline WritableDatabase::add_database(const WritableDatabase&) method
which (by C++ rules) will prevent WritableDatabase from automatically
inheriting method Database::add_database(const Database&) so attempting
to add a Database to a WritableDatabase will now give a compile-time
error.

Prior to 1.4.19, this compiled and effectively created a "black-hole"
shard which quietly discarded any changes made to it.

Already fixed on git master.  On this branch it's still possible to
perform this operation by assigning the WritableDatabase to a Database
first, but this gives an error on git master.

Reported by David Bremner on #xapian.

Avoid checking for permissions on every query

Only queries which use positional information now check, which
should help improve notmuch delete performance.  Thanks to andreas
on #notmuch for analysis of the problem.

This change isn't relevant to git master, since there we've dropped
the feature of changing OP_PHRASE and OP_NEAR to OP_AND if there
are no positions in the database being searched.

Cache result of Glass::Inverter::has_positions()

Calculating it is potentially very expensive, while maintaining a
cached answer is very cheap.

(cherry picked from commit 7345a947f67703b667bbf97422ca6f4aa084689c)

Optimise Glass::Inverter::has_positions()

Use const auto& instead of just auto for the loop variables.
Reported to be faster by andreas on #notmuch.

(cherry picked from commit 8868505bc1653239c480579847a714287e987591)

Avoid x^2 to mean x squared in comments

This is potentially confusing since in C/C++ (and some other languages),
^ means exclusive-or.  Write x² instead, which should be clear to all
readers.

(cherry picked from commit 13854225f32fa6f9bc569aa226ae0b5c636e10bb)

Don't automatically use _FORTIFY_SOURCE on mingw-w64

Recent mingw-w64 versions require -lssp to be linked when
_FORTIFY_SOURCE is enabled, so just skip the automatic enabling.
Users who want to enable it can specify it explicitly.

Fixes #808, reported by xpbxf4.

(cherry picked from commit 8c417d1ff062fd24eaf6d588ddca9b993d3c4ae7)

omega: Clamp START and END with packed timestamps

The 4-byte unsigned packed time_t format can't represent dates
before 1970 or after Sun 07 Feb 2106 06:28:15 UTC so clamp dates
before or after these - previously they would wrap around.

(cherry picked from commit ace67bd2e0f6604f4c02c0aa4b440180a67226f7)

configure: Add AC_ARG_VAR for all programs

Add missing AC_ARG_VAR for all programs so that they are documented
in --help output, and so that autoconf knows they are "precious" and
preserves them if configure is rerun when they're specified via an
environment variable.

(cherry picked from commit 298656eb2bf12914e3d2afd09fab23e447caf63f)

Add closing parenthesis to remote prog context

This has been missing since this code was first added over 20 years ago!

Spotted by Gaurav Arora.

(cherry picked from commit a5febd1b422ab82fdb1e87f7561c868b06e1cd4c)

Add usage examples for $jsonobject

(cherry picked from commit f8f9cd612598f53f4a5d63604604bbb5fedfe3c5)

Make $jsonobject output newline-free

The returned JSON no longer contains newlines, which makes it usable as
a single line serialisation format without post-processing.

(cherry picked from commit b9549f6e4adb370c135d999f47a65e43ab89a5c1)

Avoid bogus deprecation warning without optimisation

If compiling with GCC without optimisation, GCC emits a deprecation
warning for code in the definition
QueryParser::add_valuerangeprocessor() which is provided for backwards
API compatibility even if this method is never used anywhere.

This isn't helpful, especially if the user is using -Werror, so disable
the -Wdeprecated-deprecations warning for this code.

Issue specific to this branch.  Reported by starmad on #xapian.

Add workaround for testsuite failures under Wine

Attempting to unlink a stub file sometimes fails with
errno == EPERM and _doserrno == ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION.  This is
what you'd get if the file was still open, but we've already closed
it and sleeping for a second and retrying makes it work.  It'd be
better to get to the bottom of what's going on, but I've run out
of ideas and this workaround is only in the testharness at least.

(cherry picked from commit 1bb21ebad5d69747ca69b4ae607e3b4d9a9b206f)

Improve ioblock1 testcase

We were (unintentionally) trying to test with a 4TB sparse file, but
not all platforms support that.  A file just over 4GB is enough to
test what we want, and if we trying to create one fails indicating
the file size is too large (with errno EFBIG) then we skip the rest of
the testcase.

Also catch Xapian::Error exceptions and rethrow a std::string from
get_description() as the utestsuite harness doesn't know about
Xapian::Error so confusingly reports it as "UNKNOWN EXCEPTION".

Now we instead give a single error:

Split assignment and export in sh code

Combining the two (e.g. `export var=val`) is specified by POSIX but
not supported by some older shells.  Such shells may no longer be
relevant, but we avoid this in all but three cases, so let's just
fix those and not have to worry about this.

[ci] Move mingw build to GHA

GHA has the big advantage of running jobs in parallel whereas appveyor
only runs one job at a time so a complete run can take hours.  We also
now benefit from bootstrapping the tree once and on Linux so no longer
need maintainer-only dependencies.

The GHA jobs also build xapian-letor, and we now have a UCRT64 build
(which as of late 2022 is the recommended configuration to use for

[ci] Replace appveyor Cygwin job with one on GHA

The GHA job is simpler because it can use tarballs from the makedist job,

(cherry picked from commit 112c0fb119e2a033883941585d3101c0360d17ad)
[ci] Need python2-dev for Ubuntu 20.04 and later

[ci] Overhaul GHA configuration

There's now a "makedist" job which generates tarballs and stores them
in an artifact, and that's fetched and used by all the other build
jobs.

This has a number of benefits:

* It helps shake out bugs in "make dist" (this change uncovered a
  missing testdata file in the xapian-letor tarball)

* It reduces the amount of redundant work that CI has to do

* Cross-builds no longer need to do a native build just to get the
  tree bootstrapped.

* It's easier to add jobs for new platforms (via docker containers etc)
  as you don't need find a way to install the extra tools that
  bootstrapping the source tree requires, which may not be handily
  packaged.

(cherry picked from commit 7b25b8d5dc1cf34f35fead75d47ebec7b45d4e6b)

Currently, if aclocal is installed by bootstrap, it will try to find

If pkg-config was installed with homebrew, pkg.m4 would be at

need /opt/local/share/aclocal.

If we add the system path and are installing libtool, we need to always

(cherry picked from commit 047b0d160ba249709bec8533a3b7f13528d11c39)

bootstrap: Fix problem with previous change

/usr/share/aclocal to aclocal if that's needed to find pkg.m4.

[Tcl] Use TCL_SHLIB_EXT for the installed extension

Fix recovery from failed commit

If renaming to switch the new version file live fails (e.g. due to
ENOSPC) we discard the changes, try to write and switch to a different
new version file with an increased revision (on failure of this too we
close the database), and throw DatabaseError.

Unfortunately the roll-back of state is not complete, and if switching
to the different new version file succeeds that bad state persists on
disk.

Thanks to Uwe Kleine-König for reporting and coming up with the idea
to reproduce using strace to inject a rename() failure - this is a
simple reproducer:

rm -rf enospc.db
strace -e inject=rename:error=ENOSPC:when=2 examples/simpleindex enospc.db < INSTALL
xapian-check enospc.db

No automated regression test for this yet as this doesn't trivially
fit into the existing testsuite framework, but we ought to have
tests using fault injection.

[php] Redo functor reference tracking

We need to keep hold of a reference to Xapian functor objects which are
subclassed in PHP.  We were trying to use Xapian's optional reference
counting for this, but it turns out that doesn't work in the case where
the functor is set then the object it is set on is deleted, and then
the same functor object is set on another object.

It appears to be impossible to make Xapian's optional reference counting
work with SWIG director objects, so go back to keeping references via
PHP properties, but now implemented in C++ code rather than PHP code
because the classes are no longer defined in a xapian.php wrapper.

Workaround NFS issue in testsuite rm_rf()

This function is used to remove databases by the testharness.

On NFS, rmdir() can fail with EEXIST or ENOTEMPTY (POSIX allows either)
due to .nfs* files which are used by NFS clients to implement the Unix
semantics of a deleted but open file continuing to exist.  We now sleep
and retry a few times in this situation to give the NFS client a chance
to process the closing of the open handle.

Issue mentioned in #631.

Clean up handling of libs we link libxapian with

Previously any libraries explicitly specified to configure by the
user via LIBS=... and also -lm, if configure determined it is needed,
could get added to XAPIAN_LIBS multiple times, as well as also getting
added to the libxapian link command anyway as per automake/libtool
standard handling.

Now they'll only get added once, via the default handling.

Specifying a library more than once on the link line is not a problem
on common platforms, but may be an issue somewhere (and it's on less
common platforms where the user might have to specify LIBS to configure
and/or where -lm may be needed).

Enable -fno-semantic-interposition if supported

This GCC option allows the compiler to optimise essentially assuming
that functions/variables aren't replaced at dynamic link time.

Such replacement is not something that it's useful to do for Xapian
symbols, and we already turn on -Bsymbolic-functions by default which
prevents such replacement anyway by resolving references within the
library at build time.

Reduces the size of the stripped library on x86-64 Debian unstable by
~1%, and likely makes it faster too.

(cherry picked from commit 29bb8b5a3e1c0e14898acb8fe56c177f098aeecd)

Add QueryParser::FLAG_NO_POSITIONS flag

With this flag enabled, no positional information will be used and any
query operations which would use it are replaced by the nearest
equivalent which doesn't (so phrase searches, NEAR and ADJ will result
in OP_AND).  This is intended to replace the automatic conversion of
OP_PHRASE, etc to OP_AND when a database has no positional information,
which we stopped doing recently on git master.

Compile error for adding Database to WritableDatabase

Add inline WritableDatabase::add_database(const WritableDatabase&) method
which (by C++ rules) will prevent WritableDatabase from automatically
inheriting method Database::add_database(const Database&) so attempting
to add a Database to a WritableDatabase will now give a compile-time
error.

Prior to 1.4.19, this compiled and effectively created a "black-hole"
shard which quietly discarded any changes made to it.

Already fixed on git master.  On this branch it's still possible to
perform this operation by assigning the WritableDatabase to a Database
first, but this gives an error on git master.

Reported by David Bremner on #xapian.

Avoid checking for permissions on every query

Only queries which use positional information now check, which
should help improve notmuch delete performance.  Thanks to andreas
on #notmuch for analysis of the problem.

This change isn't relevant to git master, since there we've dropped
the feature of changing OP_PHRASE and OP_NEAR to OP_AND if there
are no positions in the database being searched.
